title: Has polygamy ever been practiced in a context where one woman might have multiple husbands? - Quora

response.answer_text: Yes. The practice of one woman with multiple husbands is called “polyandry.” Historically it is far rarer than polygyny, but it has been practiced in Nepal and Tibet, among other places. There’s also a variant called “Levirate polyandry” or “Leviratic polyandry” in which a woman who married a man was also considered married to his brothers under some circumstances, such as if her husband died without producing a male heir, or if she was unable to produce a male heir with her husband.

Yes, in parts of Asia. The practice is called polyandry. In Tibet, Bhutan and Ladahk it used to be pretty common for a woman to marry two men, so that when one of them disappears for a couple of months with their herds to seek out green pastures someone can stay at home and keep her company. Very often they are brothers. Tibetan Budddism is prevailant in those places and it’s quite relaxed for lay people as far as sexuality goes.

?It used to be prevalent in olden ages. Not anymore. Draupadi story is older than old. What your are talking is polyandry. One woman having more than one husbands. It should not be confused with women having multiple partners without marriage. Medically it is not safe for woman to have more partners than 1. But it is not so for male. Male is safe to have more partners than 1 (woman). EDIT: See video why?

It is starting to appear in India where their true patriarchal culture led to abortion and infanticide of all but one girl (if any were allowed) in the family. End result is 5 men (or more) per 4 women. Some families pay for smuggled in Pakistani, Nepalese or other bridges. Some men visit prostitutes and never marry. And some families find a bride for the oldest brother, then tell her she has to service all his other brothers, too.
